elements.content: To investigate the influence of the size of the aromatic chelate ligands on the frameworks of metal dicarboxylate polymers, four new coordination compounds [Co(phen)(oba)] n ·0.5nH2O (1), [Ni(phen)(oba)] n ·0.5nH2O (2), [Co2(H2O)(TATP)2(oba)2] n ·2nH2O (3), and [Ni2(H2O)(TATP)2(oba)2] n ·2nH2O (4) (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, TATP = 1,4,8,9-tetranitrogen-trisphene, oba = 4,4‘-oxybis(benzoate)) have been synthesized under similar conditions and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and X-ray crystallography. In the isomorphous 1 and 2, the metal centers are linked by bridging oba ligand to form 1-D helical chains, whereas the isomorphous 3 and 4 have extended 2-D arrays. The differences among these structures indicate that the size of the rigid aromatic chelate ligands have important effects on the structures of their complexes.

In the isomorphous 1 and 2, the metal centers are linked by bridging oba ligand to form 1-D helical chains, whereas the isomorphous 3 and 4 have extended 2-D arrays. The differences among these structures indicate that the size of the rigid aromatic chelate ligands have important effects on the structures of their complexes.

elements.content:
Structural investigation shows that pronounced changes in the size of rigid aromatic chelate ligands may influence the framework structures of metal dicarboxylate polymers.

Introduction

In recent years, the low-dimensional coordination polymers have received much attention owing to their intriguing structural features and potential as functional materials different from those of 3-D coordination polymers. Considerable progress has been made on the theoretical forecast and practical approaches aiming at controlling the topology structure and geometry of the networks to produce useful functional materials. However, the prediction of coordination frameworks is still subjective and cannot be generalized because the self-assembly progress is highly influenced by several factors, such as the metal/ligand nature, solvent, templates, and counterions. In this respect, the influence of ligand spacers of flexible bridging ligands on framework formation of their coordination polymers has widely been documented. However, the studies on the effect of the size of the N-donor chelate ligand on framework formation of their complexes have rarely been reported. In this paper, we report a series of metal dicarboxylate complexes with an N-donor chelate ligand 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) and its large analogue 1,4,8,9-tetranitrogen-trisphene (TATP) and studied the influences of the size of the aromatic chelate ligands on the framework structures of their coordination polymers, namely, [Co(phen)(oba)] n ·0.5nH2O (1), [Ni(phen)(oba)] n ·0.5nH2O (2), [Co2(H2O)(TATP)2(oba)2] n ·2nH2O (3), and [Ni2(H2O)(TATP)2(oba)2] n ·2nH2O (4) (oba = 4,4‘-oxybis(benzoate)).

elements.content: Materials and Methods. The aromatic chelate ligand TATP was synthesized according to the literature method; all other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm-1 on a Nicolet 5DX spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH-Gerätebau GmbH Thermal Analysis instrument at heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XPRD) data were recorded with a Rigaku D/max 2200 vpc diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The reflectance electronic absorption spectra were measured on a Cary 500 UV−vis−NIR spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Hydrothermal Syntheses. [Co(phen)(oba)] n · 0.5 n H 2 O (1). A mixture of Co(NO3)2·3H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), phen (0.091 g, 0.5 mmol), H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol), Et3N (0.101 g, 1 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was mixed in a 23 mL Teflon reactor, which was heated at 160 °C for 6 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 K h-1. Red block crystals (0.197 g) of 1 were obtained in 78% yield after being washed with water and dried in air. Anal. Calcd. for C26H17CoN2O5.5:  C, 61.92; H, 3.40; N, 5.55. Found:  C, 61.75; H, 3.26; N, 5.52. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3258 (s), 1685 (w), 1595 (s), 1554 (m).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer at room temperature. The data collections were performed with MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Unit cell dimensions were obtained with least squares refinements, and all structures were solved by direct method. The non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full matrix least- squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. Hydrogen atoms were added theoretically and were riding on their parent atoms. The disordered lattice water molecule in both 1 and 2 is assigned 1/2 occupancy, and the disordered lattice water molecule O3W in 3 has the occupanies of 0.55 and 0.45, respectively. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table .

Structures of [Co(phen)(oba)] n · 0.5 n H 2 O (1) and [Ni(phen)(oba)] n · 0.5 n H 2 O (2). Compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous; each contains [M(phen)(oba)] n (M = Co(II) or Ni(II)) helical chains and lattice water molecules, exhibiting only minor geometric differences. Figure a shows a fragment of the chain in the structure of 1. The Co(II) atom in 1 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two oba ligands in a bis-bidentate mode (Co1−O1A 2.137(3), Co1−O2A 2.104(3), Co1−O4 2.064(3), Co1−O5 2.216(4) Å) and two nitrogen atoms from a chelate phen (Co1−N1 2.089(4), Co1−N2 2.096(4) Å) to furnish a distorted octahedron coordination. Each oba ligand connects two cobalt or nickel centers leading to a helical chain where the Co−Co−Co or Ni−Ni−Ni angles, defined by the orientation of the oba ligands in the M(oba)2L building units (M = Co, Ni; L = phen), are 139.77(2)° in 1 and 143.17(2)° in 2. The lateral phen ligands from adjacent chains are paired to furnish moderately strong π−π stacking interactions (face−face distance ca. 3.55 Å), which extend the helical chains into wavy 2-D layers parallel to the ab plane (Figure b) in the lattice. Short C−H···O (2.157(2)−3.501(2) Å) and O−H···O (2.927(3) Å) contacts were found between the lattice water molecules, aromatic carbon atoms, and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (see Table ).

Structures of [Co 2 (H 2 O)(TATP) 2 (oba) 2 ] n · 2 n H 2 O (3) and [Ni 2 (H 2 O)(TATP) 2 (oba) 2 ] n · 2 n H 2 O (4). Similarly, 3 and 4 are also isomorphous, so that only the structure of 3 is described here. Two crystallographically unique Co(II) centers are bridged by two oba ligands and one water molecule in the asymmetric unit in 3, as shown in Figure a. Each Co(II) center is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of one TATP group (Co1−N1 2.141(2), Co1−N2 2.176(2), Co2−N5 2.121(2), Co2−N6 2.174(2) Å), three oxygen atoms from three different carboxylate groups (Co1−O1 2.128(2), Co1−O4B 2.072(2), Co1−O9A 2.072(2) Å; Co2−O5A 2.079(1), Co2−O7 2.079(2), Co2−O10A 2.076(2) Å), and one water oxygen atom (Co1−O1W 2.111(1), Co2−O1W 2.117(1) Å). Thus, each Co(II) center displays a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. One intriguing structural feature is that the water molecule (O1W) bridges two Co(II) centers in an approximately symmetric a μ-mode with the bond angle of 112.2(1)°. To our knowledge, such bridging water molecules have rarely been observed in coordination polymers. Unlike those in 1, the two carboxylate groups of the oba ligand in 3 exhibit another kind of coordination mode (i.e., monodentate−bidentate mode with one oba carboxylate end adopting a bidentate chelating mode, while another has a monodentate bridging mode). It is worthy of note that 3 (and 4) exhibits a wavelike 2-D network with unusual rhombohedral grids, which has not been observed in the {M/oba/L} system (M = transition metal; L = chelate ligand). The repeating unit of the 2-D networks possess a 12-membered ring (size ca. 12.30 × 16.09 Å2) composed of four oba ligands and eight Co(II) centers (see Figure b). Two crystallographically distinct TATP ligands (dihedral angle ca. 64.6°) extend to both sides the 2-D layer.

One intriguing structural feature is that the water molecule (O1W) bridges two Co(II) centers in an approximately symmetric a μ-mode with the bond angle of 112.2(1)°. To our knowledge, such bridging water molecules have rarely been observed in coordination polymers. Unlike those in 1, the two carboxylate groups of the oba ligand in 3 exhibit another kind of coordination mode (i.e., monodentate-bidentate mode with one oba carboxylate end adopting a bidentate chelating mode, while another has a monodentate bridging mode). It is worthy of note that 3 (and 4) exhibits a wavelike 2-D network with unusual rhombohedral grids, which has not been observed in the {M/oba/L} system (M = transition metal; L = chelate ligand). The repeating unit of the 2-D networks possess a 12-membered ring (size ca. 12.30 × 16.09 Å2) composed of four oba ligands and eight Co(II) centers (see Figure b). Two crystallographically distinct TATP ligands (dihedral angle ca. 64.6°) extend to both sides the 2-D layer.

elements.content: In the packing arrangement of 3 (Figure ), the 2-D layers are almost parallel with each other, which are packed in an ABAB arrangement to furnish a 3-D framework via the π−π interactions. One of the crystallographically distinct TATP ligands intercalates the closest layer to form a double layer structure with π−π stacking interactions (3.61 Å) between the aromatic groups of TATP and oba ligands, whereas another TATP ligand is involved in an offset face-to-face π−π interaction (ca. 3.34 Å) with a TATP ligand from an adjacent double layer to furnish the 3-D structure. Strong hydrogen bonding interactions between the carboxylate oxygen atoms of oba ligands, carbon atoms of TATP ligands, and the coordinated water molecules further consolidate the structure, and the detailed geometric data are listed in Table .

elements.content: There are two lattice water molecules in per formula unit, which is further supported by thermogravimetric analyses results. The TG curve of 3 shows that the weight loss of 3.19% between room temperature and 150 °C corresponds to the removal of two lattice water molecules (calculated 3.13) (Figure S1). The valence sum calculations give the value of 2.0 for the Co1 atom and 2.1 for Co2 atom, indicating that both Co centers are in the +2 oxidation state. The coordinated water O1W and uncoordinated O(2) atoms of the oba ligands have bond valence sums of 0.619 and 1.456, respectively. These values suggest that O1W is a coordinated water molecule, while O(2) is a deprotonated oxygen atom of the carboxylate group.

elements.content: IR Spectra, XRPD Patterns, and Electronic Spectra. The IR spectra of 1 − 4 showing the absence of strong peaks around 1700 cm-1 indicates that all carboxylic groups are deprotonated, which is consistent with the results of the X-ray analysis. The simulated and experimental XRPD patterns of 1 − 4 are shown in Figure S2. Their peak positions are in good agreement with each other, indicating the phase purity of the products. The differences in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples. The diffuse reflectance UV−vis spectra for H2oba, phen, TATP, and 1−4 show different absorption features (Figure ). In comparison with the bands of ligands, the shorter wavelength absorptions in the UV region for 1−4 (i.e., 217 and 248 nm for 1, 221 and 257 nm for 2, 243 nm for 3, and 255 nm for 4) do not show very significant changes, corresponding to the intraligand π−π* transitions of ligands. On the other hand, the longer wavelength band in the UV region shifts toward lower energy upon coordination, which may arise from the n −π* transition perturbed by the Co2+ or Ni2+ ions. It is noted that the absorption intensity of the coordination polymers is markedly higher than that for either of the ligands. This significant increase in absorption intensity is attributable to the involvement of charge-transfer transitions from the O atoms of the ligands to the empty 4s orbitals of the Co2+ or Ni2+ ions.

elements.content: The shoulder visible absorption bands of 1 and 3 at ca. 515 nm and wide ones of 2 and 4 at ca. 650 nm give characteristics different from those of the ligand itself. The absorption bands in this region are found to be primarily influenced by the kinds of metal ions but not by substituent groups, which is different from the absorption spectra of [Ni(β-diketonato)2(NIT2-py)] and [Ni(β-diketonato)(tmen)(NIT2-py)]; the positions of these components are shifted to higher frequency by substituting the methyl group for the phenyl group and/or for the trifluoromethyl group. Their intensities are much larger than those of the ligand itself. From these spectral behaviors, the visible bands may be assigned to neither the intraligand nor the charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions but to the d−d transitions.

elements.content: Dicarboxylate ligands are a kind of important bridging in the construction of coordination architectures with metal ions, adopting a different coordination mode in the coordination architecture. The presence of chelate ligands in transition metal dicarboxylate systems usually results in the formation of low-dimensional coordination polymers with the metal ions acting as nodes and the dicarboxylate ligands as connectors, especially 1-D chains, and the employment of a V-shaped dicarboxylate may generate helical chains. The incorporation of the coordinating water molecule, which plays a major role in determining the coordination mode of dicarboxylate ligands and the degree of bending of the chain, is primarily influenced by the size of chelate ligands. Their bridging modes are highly dependent on the coordination modes of dicarboxylate ligands, which can affect the final structural motifs of the polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Dicarboxylate ligands are a kind of important bridging in the construction of coordination architectures with metal ions, adopting a different coordination mode in the coordination architecture. The presence of chelate ligands in transition metal dicarboxylate systems usually results in the formation of low-dimensional coordination polymers with the metal ions acting as nodes and the dicarboxylate ligands as connectors, especially 1-D chains, and the employment of a V-shaped dicarboxylate may generate helical chains. The incorporation of the coordinating water molecule, which plays a major role in determining the coordination mode of dicarboxylate ligands and the degree of bending of the chain, is primarily influenced by the size of chelate ligands. Their bridging modes are highly dependent on the coordination modes of dicarboxylate ligands, which can affect the final structural motifs of the polymers.

elements.content: As expected, 1 and 2 are 1-D chain structures, in which the metal ion exhibits octahedron coordination, and the carboxy groups have a chelating bidentate bridging mode. In the similar polymers [Cu(oba) (phen)] n , [Cu(oba)(2,2-bpy)] n , and [Co(oba)(phen)(H2O)2] n synthesized under similar reaction conditions, the structure of [Cu(oba)(phen)] n comprises neutral double-stranded helices in which the oba ligands adopt bis(monodentate) coordination mode, each CuII atom adopts four-coordinated square-planar geometry, and Cu−Cu−Cu angles are 52.8°. The phen ligands are extended in a parallel fahion at both sides of a single-stranded chain with a face−face distance of 6.84 Å, a pair of such chains interwines into a unique double-stranded helix through the π−π stacking interactions. Similar to that of 1/2, the CuII atom in [Cu(oba)(2,2-bpy)] n is also pseudo-octahedrally coordinated, in which Cu−Cu−Cu angles are 133.4°. In [Co(oba)(phen)(H2O)2] n , each Co(II) ion is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two bis-monodentate oba ligands, two nitrogen atoms from a phen ligand, and two coordinated water molecules, generating a double-stranded chain, which is different from that of [Cu(oba)(phen)] n and may be attributed to the different coordination environments of Co2+ and Cu2+ ions. Major structural differences between 1 and [Co(oba)(phen)(H2O)2] n lie in the incorporation of the coordinating water molecules in the latter, which hence has a different coordination mode of oba ligand and a more bended chain. In this context, we may conclude that the bending degree of the chains increases when a larger chelate ligand or incorporation of coordinating water molecule, as well as that the coordination number and/or coordination geometry of the metal center and coordination modes of dicarboxylate ligands have profound influences on the final structural motif.

In the similar polymers [Cu(oba) (phen)] n , [Cu(oba)(2,2-bpy)] n , and [Co(oba)(phen)(H2O)2] n  synthesized under similar reaction conditions, the structure of [Cu(oba)(phen)] n  comprises neutral double-stranded helices in which the oba ligands adopt bis(monodentate) coordination mode, each CuII atom adopts four-coordinated square-planar geometry, and Cu-Cu-Cu angles are 52.8°. The phen ligands are extended in a parallel fahion at both sides of a single-stranded chain with a face-face distance of 6.84 Å, a pair of such chains interwines into a unique double-stranded helix through the π-π stacking interactions. Similar to that of 1/2, the CuII atom in [Cu(oba)(2,2-bpy)] n  is also pseudo-octahedrally coordinated, in which Cu-Cu-Cu angles are 133.4°. In [Co(oba)(phen)(H2O)2] n , each Co(II) ion is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two bis-monodentate oba ligands, two nitrogen atoms from a phen ligand, and two coordinated water molecules, generating a double-stranded chain, which is different from that of [Cu(oba)(phen)] n  and may be attributed to the different coordination environments of Co2+ and Cu2+ ions. Major structural differences between 1 and [Co(oba)(phen)(H2O)2] n  lie in the incorporation of the coordinating water molecules in the latter, which hence has a different coordination mode of oba ligand and a more bended chain. In this context, we may conclude that the bending degree of the chains increases when a larger chelate ligand or incorporation of coordinating water molecule, as well as that the coordination number and/or coordination geometry of the metal center and coordination modes of dicarboxylate ligands have profound influences on the final structural motif.

elements.content: In contrast to 1/2, 3/4 is unexpected despite that their synthetic conditions are very similar, and the main difference between those for 1/2 and 3/4 is the chelate ligands of different sizes. Generally, the results of substitutions of phen with larger TATP result in the incorporation of the coordinating water molecule and increase the bended degree of the chain, being evident from the M−M−M angle changed from ca. 140 to 90°, due to the aromatic−aromatic interactions and the steric hindrance. There is interesting intramolecular hydrogen bonding between hydrogen atoms of the bridging water molecule and nearby carboxylate groups in 3 and 4. These interactions stabilize the free carboxylate groups in the structure. The formation of the μ-OH2 group and the dinuclear subunit in 3 and 4 may be attributed to intramolecular hydrogen bonding between the bridging water molecule and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms, as well as the aromatic−aromatic interactions of the larger chelate ligand. The resulting dinuclear subunits acting as four-connecting nodes can now be interconnected by the dicarboxylate ligands functioning as connectors into a 2-D net.

The resulting dinuclear subunits acting as four-connecting nodes can now be interconnected by the dicarboxylate ligands functioning as connectors into a 2-D net.

elements.content: In summary, we successfully synthesized four new coordination polymers in the {M/oba/L} system (M = transition metal; L = chelate ligand) under similar reaction conditions. With smaller L = phen, both 1 and 2 are 1-D helical chains, while with larger L = TATP, both 3 and 4 are 2-D networks. These results indicate that the changes of the size of the rigid aromatic chelate ligands, adapting the coordination modes of dicarboxylate ligands from a chelating to a monodentate modes accompanied by incorporation of the coordinating water, may have significant effect on the framework structures of the coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we successfully synthesized four new coordination polymers in the {M/oba/L} system (M = transition metal; L = chelate ligand) under similar reaction conditions. With smaller L = phen, both 1 and 2 are 1-D helical chains, while with larger L = TATP, both 3 and 4 are 2-D networks. These results indicate that the changes of the size of the rigid aromatic chelate ligands, adapting the coordination modes of dicarboxylate ligands from a chelating to a monodentate modes accompanied by incorporation of the coordinating water, may have significant effect on the framework structures of the coordination polymers.

cln_elements.content:
Hydrothermal Syntheses. [Co(phen)(oba)] n · 0.5 n H 2 O (1). A mixture of Co(NO3)2·3H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), phen (0.091 g, 0.5 mmol), H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol), Et3N (0.101 g, 1 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was mixed in a 23 mL Teflon reactor, which was heated at 160 °C for 6 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 K h-1. Red block crystals (0.197 g) of 1 were obtained in 78% yield after being washed with water and dried in air. Anal. Calcd. for C26H17CoN2O5.5:  C, 61.92; H, 3.40; N, 5.55. Found:  C, 61.75; H, 3.26; N, 5.52. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3258 (s), 1685 (w), 1595 (s), 1554 (m).

[Ni(phen)(oba)] n · 0.5 n H 2 O (2). A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.5 mmol), phen (0.5 mmol), H2oba (0.129 g, 0.5 mmol), Et3N (0.101 g, 1 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was mixed in a 23 mL Teflon reactor, which was heated at 160 °C for 6 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 K h-1. Green block crystals of 2 (0.151 g) were obtained in 60% yield after being washed with water and dried in air. Anal. Calcd. for C26H17N2NiO5.5:  C, 61.95; H, 3.40; N, 5.56. Found:  C, 61.68; H, 3.65; N, 5.48. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3435 (w), 1685 (w), 1598 (s), 1524 (s).

[Co 2 (H 2 O)(TATP) 2 (oba) 2 ] n · 2 n H 2 O (3). Compound 3 was prepared as for 1 by using TATP (0.118 g, 0.5 mmol) in place of phen. Red block crystals of 3 (0.804 g) were isolated in 70% yield. Anal. calcd. for C56H38Co2N8O13:  C, 58.55; H, 3.33; N, 9.75. Found:  C 58.81, H 3.10, N 9.80. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3072 (m), 1685 (s), 1594 (s), 1502 (m).

[Ni 2 (H 2 O)(TATP) 2 (oba) 2 ] n · 2 n H 2 O (4). Compound 4 was prepared as for 2 by using TATP (0.118 g, 0.5 mmol) instead of phen. Green block crystals of 4 (0.643 g) were isolated in 56% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C56H38N8Ni2O13:  C, 58.57; H, 3.34; N, 9.76. Found:  C, 58.67; H, 3.45; N, 9.58. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3383 (m), 1626 (s), 1596 (s), 1530 (w).
